description: From Middle English undermele, undermel (“the early part of the afternoon, midday, noon; an afternoon meal or nap”), from Old English undernmǣl (“morning, morning time; morning meal”), equivalent to undern +‎ meal. Compare the word for midday and the word undern.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Synonym of undern: originally terce and the morning, later (UK, dialectal, obsolete) noon and the early afternoon.
examples: By the time—he hath din'd at a taverne, and slept his undermeals at a bawdy-house, his purse is [empty].

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Synonym of siesta: an afternoon nap.
examples: In a narrower limit than the forty years' undermeal of the seven sleepers.
Another great supper, or undermeal, was made ready for them, coming home from ditching and plowing.
